last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1868775
Here’s my shelf. All the vertical blue books on the left are from the USMM federal academy curriculum and most of the USCG test question database draws directly from the materials within.
The horizontal book on the top is a personal favorite of mine.

“Fireman NAVEDTRA 10520-G”
Unfortunately it’s been out of print for decades but it’s THE BEST one volume illustrated book for teaching basic oiler knowledge of pipes and valves and pumps. Find a copy if you can.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1867668
It worked for a married couple i knew who were both mariners. Lived in a 26" sailboat moored close to where our company boats were. They got by in a non live-in berth because they kept a low profile and were often gone for long periods. Saved them a ton of money since this was in a major west coast city with crazy rent and housing prices.

>>1868609
Read the sticky, swab.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1868973
I should add that the black bound "Basic Electricity" book on the right of the picture is often touted as the go to for starting your self education on electricity. Its a reprint of another old NAVPERS/NAVEDTRA manual.
However IMO it is written in such an obtuse old style that it gets in its own way when trying to get the information accross. A much better modern text is the "Navy Electricity and
Electronics Training Series"
"NAVEDTRA 14173"
Modules 1-5 will teach you most of whats relevant, in a much more direct style obviously written for entry level enlisted naval students.
They are available as free .PDF online.

On the far right are a collection of random NJATC textbooks on motor controllers, which are extremely common onboard ships and these manuals are written again for entry level young students starting a career in industrial electrical service. Great illustrations and explanations.
"Industrial electricity and Motor Controls" by Miller and Miller is another text that the USCG draws on for questions, but its written for a higher level than the NJATC books and has older illustrations. Still worth getting if you want to study the exact test material.

>Russia, in a way, shows that without governmental input, trucks remain a solution to the last mile problem.
They're used for transport in basically all distance bands in Russia. Ton-km is a generally a good metric, but it's distorted in Russia because much of what they do is moving raw materials from Siberia into Europe or the Urals or China, and because purchasing power/the consumer goods market is lower than in other countries.
But median distance trucks travel is still 2/3 that of the US, which implies a decent amount of stuff being shipped end-to-end on trucks.

Did you ever notice that aerogels don't actually float, despite supposedly being lighter than air? That's because they actually aren't. Their external volume divided by their weight is less than the density of air, but that's because internally they are full of holes and bubbles in which air can go through, so their actual density is the same as the material they are made of, which if it's silica is similar to sand.

>>1865026
Lightweight vaccum containers are possible, the problem is that the skin material would be subject to compression instead of tension like in an pressure tank, so it's vulnerable to buckling rather than simple structural strenght so it has to be made much thicker. Hydrogen gas H2 has about 10% of air's density so it's not really woth the improvement.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

But aerogel can't trap hydrogen within itself, you'd need to envelop it with a gas bag to do so and that weights more than the gas bag by itself. The problem with aerogels is that they are stiff but brittle, so they have to be employed very carefully.

WRONG. Open fires and sparks were strictly VERBOTEN on the airships, because there was constant loss of hydrogen (which is normal since the gas bags aren't 100% hermetically sealed and it's compensated by the fuel being used up). The smoking room was a separate room that was specially ventilated and slightly pressurised to avoid posing any danger. This smoking room had the only accessible lighter on board the ship.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1868529
Open fires and sparks are stricly forbidden on airplanes too, because both are often built with lightweight materials like aluminium, magnesium, wood and plastic which have the side effect of catching fire surprisingly quickly and violently.

Hydrogen leaks are a common, but once free hydrogen tends to go upwards because it's so light, while the passenger galley is bellow the gas bags. The point of the smoking rooms ventilation and pressurization is to avoid spreads smoke and ash throught the rest of the ship where it might pose a danger, rather than preventing hydrogen from getting in.

threads.com: Why don't you ride an electric unicycle? Don't you want to effortlessly zoom around at 30mph/50kph with no hands?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1867731
>>1867762
TLDR: unstoppable faceplant.

Note that at low speeds (5-6mph) you land standing up, while the wheel gets it unstoppable faceplant.
Also note that falling of a bike/motorbike is usually way more dangerous because of its weight crashing on your body.
Also note that with a few exceptions, EUC riders fully gear up, while motorbike riders wear a helmet and that's all. (No, gloves meant to keep your hands warm don't count as protection).
I faceplanted @ 18mph, destroyed my 200 bucks trousers, earned some scratches, a few weeks later no pain anymore. Go try falling off a bike at 18mph

BTW EUC's are spectacularly simple. A derated DC motor (because battery constraints), always on, always engaged, and a controller board. Except serious cases of bad maintenance, motor won't fail. It will be either the controller board or the battery, and it will only happen because of some superbly low quality component (say, prone-to-fail cells, shitty MOSFETs, etc).

last_replies.name: Anonymous

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1868046
If by "they" you mean mountain bikers and the french. Just use the iso measurement to make sure the tyre fits your rim and the tyre width to make sure it'll fit in your frame. Or just get the same size as the tyre you're replacing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There are wheel sizes and tire sizes. Don't think of wheel sizes as standards or measurements. They're names. If you have a 700c wheel you need 700c tires.
If you have a 26" wheel you need 26" tires. It's quite simple.

Tire sizes are measured in mm, or, for larger sizes, inches. That is an actual rough measurement of the width of the tire. What size tire you can fit is something you can measure.

Most planes default to flying straight and level even without a pilot, the only situation where it is objectively necessary to have the computer keep straight a level as much as possible would be on an aerodynamically unstable airplane like an f-16, which will pitch violently in short order if there's no correction.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1866353
Not exactly. They had some racing heritage, even so this isn't the reason they went under. They had success before and during the bike boom but this made them too comfortable. During the bike boom, the U.S. enjoyed a better selection of racier, lighter bikes from recent import from Europe and Japan, and American customers sort of realized that American bike manufacturers, even if they made bikes that looked like road bikes (Varsity, Continental, Super Sport etc), were about 5-10 years behind in terms of technology especially regarding frame tubing. Boomers will cope and say that they are heavy because they are bomb-proof, but the maybe small drop in durability of the foreign bikes was worth the weight savings. These American "racy" looking bikes were just absolute boat anchors, and even shitty Peugeot gaspipe shitters were lighter. American tastes had changed a little by the end of the bike boom.
Eventually Schwinn realized the changing market but was a little late to react to the change. They pretty much never recovered from this. Eventually they tried to get people back with cheaper and sportier frames made in Taiwan and Japan, but the damage had already been done. Their reputation as low-tech, heavy bikes went with them into the 80s. This foreign manufacture also sort of ruined their image as The American Bicycle Manufacturer. What was the point of the company if half their frames were foreign?This meant that from the 80s on was all an effort to slow down how hard they were falling. It's a shame because they really made some nice stuff in the late 80s/early 90s, especially the Japanese stuff.
TLDR Schwinn got too comfortable from their success from having a monopoly on American sales for decades, and didn't advance their tech fast enough. When they finally had advanced competition from outside America they got left behind and never recovered.

Zurichs good urbanism can be traced back to the early 20th century, and has mostly benefitted from simply not ripping up half the city to make room for cars, or not getting rid of trams. Many of these things were the result of a relatively conservative population, for example voting against the subway project in the 1970s. The high level of attention public transport gets in Switzerland is in no way limited to leftist governments, as cities or regions that are more conservative still tend the same policies.

Most cases of bad urbanism stem from undoing the good work of pre-WW2 era, rather than from progressive/leftist policies, which, though generally less car-oriented which is good, suffer from a lack of pragmatism. For example, Barcelona is working to reduce car-centric urban design, but all the while barely expanding public transit, which is extremely saturated within the city and very inconvenient on certain itineraries. Of course you're not going to get people out of their cars if the alternative to a 20 minute drive is an hour riding two buses. The result is that traffic has actually gotten worse in the past couple of years, and more and more people are using scooters which are then parked on the widened sidewalks, making the whole work of expanding those sidewalks pointless. Meanwhile a bunch of bike paths which only appeal to the yuppies who can still afford to actually live in the city center aren't resolving anything, either, just taking away space direly needed for wider bus lanes, because the existing ones are so narrow the buses still get stuck in traffic as they can't overtake the cars. So while the intentions are good, the implementation is abhorrent, because it's too far up its own ass and not taking account more practical considerations.
(1/2)

How to ride bikes on streets without bike lanes:
- TAKE THE FULL LANE. Do NOT ride on the the edge of the road if there is not enough space for cars to safely pass you. You WILL get clipped up by a driver if you're stupid enough to ride on the edge of roads.
- Switching from riding on the street to the sidewalk is valid. Fuck drivers and fuck pedestrians that whine "muh cyclists are pedestrians or vehicles when the feel like it". Your safety is more important than their feelings.
- At the least wear bright (white or light color top) clothing if you're riding late or at night. Reflective clothing is best.
- Use your hand signals.
- If you are going to be an annoyance to car traffic (cycling less than 20 MPH, riding up a hill, etc.) then use the sidewalk.

How to ride bikes on the sidewalk:
- Pedestrians have priority. Say "EXCUSE ME!" or "ON YOUR LEFT!" to alert them. Slow down around children and groups.
- If you see a bunch of retards not moving out your way (usually teenagers) and they obviously see you, don't slow down. #FuckThemKids
- Cars do not see you. Slow the FUCK down at all driveways and intersections. Look back and make sure a driver isn't about to turn right on red and right-hook you. Make sure traffic is clear before going through. Most bike accidents occur at intersections.

last_replies.com:
Gore shake dry should be the absolute most water repellent and among the lightest. But its fragile, can't wear a backpack with it, and should avoid riding where you would scrape against streets.

There's a difference between losing water repellency and not being waterproof. Gore shake dry eliminates the bonded surface fabric which absorbs water after the surface treatment wears out and uses just the waterproof membrane.

I've heard good things about Neoshell's breatheability.

Some of the perforated poly urathane rain jackets have decent breatheability (not as good as the fancier stuff) with a silicone exterior. I've got a sugoi one I've worn for daylong randonneur rides.

Regardless of what you pick if there is 100% humidity in the air, the sweat vapor you generate inside a jacket isn't going anywhere.
